Putin Cautions Bush On Missile Defense Shield President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia cautioned President Bush about developing a missile defense shield without Moscow's consent, telling Mr. Bush that such an action could seriously strain relations between the two countries.

Exodus From Rural Mexico Swaths of central Mexico are gradually being abandoned as illegal crossings from Mexico to the United States become so difficult -- and even deadly, migration experts say -- that many migrants and their families choose to settle permanently in the United States.

Annan Urges Mideast Peace The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, urged Israelis and Palestinians to take advantage of a crucial moment of relative calm to move toward resuming peace talks in the region.

Sudanese Suspect Arrested A Sudanese man, Abdil Rauf Hawas, suspected of working for the Islamic militant Osama bin Laden was arrested along with an Indian accomplice, Shamim Sarvar, for allegedly planning to blow up the American Embassy in India, domestic news agencies reported.
(AP)

Rebels Release 3 Filipinos Three Filipino hostages held by Muslim guerrillas were reunited with their families after trudging for two days through the jungle. One of the freed captives said he had seen two of the three American hostages three days earlier but had no word on the third, Guillermo Sobero of Corona, Calif., whom the rebels claimed to have beheaded.
(AP)
NATIONAL

New Allegations Raised Against Roger Clinton A Texas entrepreneur has told federal investigators that he gave Roger Clinton, Bill Clinton's half brother, $30,000 in cash to help him get two diplomatic passports. He says Roger Clinton also promised to secure a presidential pardon for an acquaintance.

More Single Fathers The number of single fathers with primary custody of their children has risen more than 50 percent from 1990 to 2000, one of the most striking trends to emerge from recent census data.

Rethinking Capital Punishment After a decade in which there appeared to be an unshakable near consensus in favor of the death penalty, Americans are now debating it as a moral issue the way they argue over abortion.
Milestone for Chelsea Clinton Chelsea Clinton graduates from Stanford University today, her privacy remarkably intact despite years in the spotlight.
More Protests Over Vieques Protesters plan to continue their campaign against Navy exercises on Vieques. President Bush has said military training on the Puerto Rican island will end in 2003.
SCIENCE/HEALTH

New Tactic for Global Warming Scientists trying to combat the so-called greenhouse effect are looking for new ways to capture carbon dioxide emissions from smokestacks and store the gas out of contact with the atmosphere.
NEW YORK/REGION

Seeking a Death Certificate For Boy Missing For 22 Years On Tuesday Stanley K. Patz's lawyer will ask a judge to declare his missing son, Etan, legally dead. Etan, then 6, was last seen on May 25, 1979, as he left his SoHo home to catch the bus for school. With his son declared dead, Mr. Patz could pursue a wrongful-death lawsuit against a convicted pedophile in Pennsylvania who he believes killed the boy.

No Ikea for Brooklyn Plans by Ikea, the Swedish furniture retailer, to purchase a nine-acre site near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn and build a 300,000-square-foot store there have fallen through, the developer who had been negotiating with the furniture chain said. Brooklyn residents and elected officials opposed to the plan had voiced concerns about traffic and pollution.

Christie's Amnesty Challenged Lawyers for A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's who was indicted on antitrust charges last month, are challenging the conditional amnesty granted to Sotheby's archrival Christie's after the two auction houses were charged with collusion.

Arguments About Tests The standardized test movement was supposed to do away with the elitist notion that there are two different tracks in school, for smart and not-so-smart students. Others, though, say that given the range of human ability, it is inevitable that there will be different tracks.
